awd_titl_txt: REU site: REU Molecular Biology and Genetics of Cell Signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Cornell University, located in Ithaca, NY, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during summers of 2017-2019. The broad theme is "Molecular Biology and Genetics of Cell Signaling".  While the program is housed in the Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics (MBG), about a third of the 24 participating faculty are members of other departments. The MBG REU program is integrated with the Cornell Summer Institute for Life Science (SILS), the umbrella unit covering research for about 100 Cornell biology majors. In addition to laboratory research itself, the MBG REU program includes weekly talks by faculty on the broad aspects of cell signaling, weekly meetings to discuss what to expect in graduate school, and informal instruction on how to prepare research talks and posters.  Among other activities is a popular workshop on responsible conduct of research, attended by some 100 undergrad students. The MBG REU program is explicitly focused on diversity in its broad sense. Students, preferably sophomores or juniors, can apply to the program directly at the website link provided below. Participating students, selected from the application pool by a faculty committee, will come primarily from schools with limited research opportunities. The overarching goal of the program is to allow students to participate directly in cutting edge research in the broad areas of molecular and cell biology, biochemistry, biophysics, developmental biology, or genetics and genomics.  Many of the students will present the results of their work at scientific conferences, and all will make presentations in a local poster session and a short talk.   

     A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the NSF Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://mbg.cornell.edu/undergraduate/summer-research-experience, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Volker M. Vogt at vmv1@cornell.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Kelly Liu at jl53@cornell.edu).

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this REU program was to create a nurturing environment in which students could conduct cutting-edge research, discover if they have a passion for research, and make informed decisions regarding graduate school and careers in modern biological sciences. In particular, the program aimed to provide significant hands-on experiences to students who were currently underrepresented in STEM fields, specifically minority and first-generation college students, and students from non-PhD granting small colleges that do not provide significant research opportunities.

Between 2017 and 2021, with a gap in 2020 due to the pandemic, the program supported a total of 34 REU students. The impact of the program was further increased by the additional 8 undergraduates who were funded by other mechanisms but participated fully in all aspects of this REU program. Among past participants, 60% were underrepresented minority students, 35% were first-generation college students, and more than 60% came from small non-PhD granting colleges.

The research focus of this program was in the field of molecular signaling, a process that is fundamental to almost every cellular event. All of the more than 20 participating faculty conducted basic, curiosity-driven research in the general area of molecular signaling. During the 10-week summer program, each REU student delved into a particular area of molecular signaling through their individual research projects, guided by the faculty and lab mentors. REU students also attended weekly scientific talks, which provided them with a broader view of the signaling field. In addition, REU students attended workshops on lab safety, research ethics, statistics, database searching and citation management, as well as a number of other career development workshops that allowed them to improve their communication skills, and that provided information about graduate school. At the end of the program, each REU student gave a poster presentation and a 10 min talk. Multiple REU students attended and presented their work from the REU program at national or local research conferences after the end of the program. Many of them received outstanding presentation awards. Multiple REU students also co-authored papers published in top tier research journals based on research they conducted in our REU program. Several students subsequently received prestigious awards, such as the Goldwater Scholarship and the HHMI Gilliam Fellowship for Advanced Study. Details on these as well as the presentation and publication records of the REU students can be found at: https://mbg.cornell.edu/undergraduate/summer-research-experience/outcomes/.

Post-program student surveys showed that, as a result of their research experiences in our program, 100% of the students reported that they had a good to great gain in their confidence to do research and in understanding what everyday research is like, and 94% said that their REU research experience prepared them for graduate school. Tracking of past REU students shows that most of these students are attending graduate school or pursuing STEM careers; 74% of those who have graduated are currently enrolled in PhD programs in top research institutions such as Stanford, Yale, U Penn, Cornell, among others; 16% are currently enrolled in MS programs or have obtained an MS degree and are working in the STEM field.

In summary, the MBG-REU program at Cornell University has been successful in attracting a diverse pool of students and providing them with cutting-edge research experiences in the molecular biosciences. Through these experiences, the students have gained confidence in research and become better prepared for graduate school as well as for future research careers in academia or industry.
